Award.AwardTitle: Development of Novel Detection and Prediction Algorithms for Microsystis Blooms
Award.AbstractNarration:
Cyanobacteria-dominated harmful algal blooms (HABs) currently pose a serious health and economic risk to inhabitants and users of the Great Lakes, often producing toxins in sufficient quantity to cause severe health problems to humans and animals. The Great Lakes are a vital national resource, given they are the largest surface freshwater system on earth and provide drinking water for more than 40 million people. Current observational platforms have been focused on the nutrient and phytoplankton ecology measurements. There has been very little effort to characterize the optical variability associated with the HABs in the Great Lakes.

In this project, a research team at the University of New Hampshire and the University of Wisconsin - Madison, in collaboration with the NOAA Great Lakes Environmental Research Laboratory, will develop these capabilities with state-of-the-art instrumentation aimed at detecting HAB events as they initiate while capturing the environmental conditions that promote them. There are two main objectives: (1) to develop a new quantitative detection algorithm for HABs in the Great Lakes based on remote sensing imagery by refining and augmenting currently qualitative algorithms; and (2) to develop an ecological niche model to predict the onset of HABs in the Great Lakes with inputs from remotely-sensed data products and state-of-the-art in-situ environmental measurements. One component will consist of implementing a monitoring program consisting of autonomous measurements - combined with ship measurements - of environmental parameters in western Lake Erie and Saginaw Bay critical to HAB initiation and promotion. These measurements will be used in the development of new satellite products that can provide synoptic observation of environmental signatures of these toxic algal blooms. They will combine these new satellite products with other synoptic satellite environmental products and available in-situ environmental measurements to construct an historical data set that characterizes HAB events in the context of associated environmental conditions that cultivate the blooms. This data set will guide the development of an innovative ecological niche model based on multivariate analysis that will predict the spatial and temporal distribution of imminent HAB events from real-time environmental inputs. The overall intellectual merit of the work lies in enhanced observational and detection approaches through remote sensing technology application, and an improved understanding of bloom development leading to better predictive tools.

Broader Impacts. This work will add considerable observational information related to HABs for this and future studies in the Great Lakes and other freshwater systems. Secondly, it will lead to increased understanding of the ecology of these blooms that will better assist and inform water quality policy decisions. Our ultimate aim is to develop a critical set of tools for effectively managing human health risks associated with cyanobacterial blooms in water bodies around the globe

JOINT FUNDING BY NSF AND NIEHS: The original proposal on which this project is based (R01 ES021929-01) was submitted to the National Institutes of Environmental Health Sciences (NIH/NIEHS) in response to Funding Opportunity Announcement RFA-ES-11-013 , "Oceans, Great Lakes and Human Health (R01)", an opportunity jointly sponsored by NSF. This project is cooperatively funded through separate awards from NSF and NIEHS.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our study focused on improving the remote sensing detection of freshwater harmful algal blooms comprising cyanobacteria in the Great Lakes of North America.  A main component of the study was to collect observational field data in Lake Erie in the summers of 2013 and 2014.  We deployed an in-water buoy system that measured water quality properties real-time and disseminated the data to a website portal for real-time display.  We also conducted several spatial surveys that focused on collecting high-quality bio-optical data using state-of-the-art instruments. The optical data we collected was comprehensive and included spectral absorption and scattering properties of bloom and non-bloom waters, and other measurements critical for remote sensing.  Analysis of the data has shown new inisights into the optical and ecoloigcal properties of cyanobacteria blooms, particulary the impacts of colonies on absorption and backscattering which is greatly enhanced.  This elevates light levels leaving the water column at specific wavelengths, relevant to remote sensing applications.  Further, data collected from a digital holographic imager revealed deviations from expected size distrubutions in Microcystis waters due to the colonies, and indicated  active vertical migration towards the surface in these waters.  Adjacent waters in the central basin of Lake Erie were dominated by another cyanobacteria Planktothrix, which showed different optical properties and vertical size distributions consistent with their ecological preference for lower light levels and away from the surface.  These findings have important implications towards the remote sensing applications of cyanobacteria blooms, and highlight the challenges associated with these unique optical conditions. The data we colleted will be useful for both satellite algorithm analyis and ecological analysis in years to come, as the data set is unique and sheds new light on natural cynoabacteria assemblages.   

Out of this work, we also developed a chlorophyll algorithm blending scheme adapted from the optical water type framework for marine waters.  This new scheme is more lake oriented, and blends a low and high chlorophyll algorithm together in a seamless fashion for remote sensing images over Lake Erie through a classification scheme, but is broadly applicable to other lakes.  The scheme has been shown to be an effective way to reduce algorithm uncertainties.  The scheme has taken root elsewhere, and has been revised by two other lake research group projects in Europe.  The rationale behind these schemes is that a single algorithm is not capable of working with precision across the large range of conditions that lakes exhibit.  There is also ecological information contained in the intermediary products from the classification scheme.  These intermediary products depict the fuzzy memberships to a priori spectral shapes.  Trend analysis of these image sets provide important information on the spatial and temporal trends of optical states from satellite data, providing additional informational on quantifying the nature of optical conditions in a lake system. 

Overall, our study has revealed important optical information on natural cyanobacteria assemblages, particularly vacuolated species, relevant to remote senising.  With the availability of new sets of satelllite imagery from sensors that have high spatial resolution, the use of lake remote sensing for monitoring cyanobacteria blooms will likely increase in the coming years, and the outcomes from this study will be highly relevant for this new era.
